newsitem.title: UK: Oil prices climb again as Lebed sacked, low stocks.
newsitem.headline: Oil prices climb again as Lebed sacked, low stocks.

text.p: Oil prices strode higher again on Thursday, wiping out losses which had been prompting some speculation that a startling rally might have run its course.
London December futures for international benchmark Brent crude at 1515 GMT traded up 35 cents at $24.30 a barrel.

Dealers said the sacking on Thursday of Russian security chief Alexander Lebed, underlining political instability at the heart of one of the world's biggest oil producers, again unsettled oil markets.
Weekly U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) data confirming the tight picture on heating oil markets as winter approached also helped bolster prices.
U.S. heating oil stocks were down 27 percent against the same time last year with key east coast inventories off a huge 43 percent, the DOE said.
"Every time this market seems ready for a substantial correction, it bounces back again," said a London-based trader.

"The fact the market was happy to shift higher again just underlines how susceptible it is to the merest hint of supply disruption," said another. November Brent futures earlier this week broke $25 for the first time in nearly six years as traders fretted over the possibility of a shortage of heating oil supplies in the West this winter.

But prices went into reverse on Wednesday, dipping below $24 amid talk that the U.S. government might intervene to protect heating oil consumers this winter, possibly by encouraging a clampdown on exports.
High European prices have allowed traders to make money by selling more than a million tonnes of heating oil from U.S. markets to European buyers over the past two months.
The exports have exacerbated U.S. inventory shortfalls.

U.S. oil company executives will meet Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary and a Justice Department representative on Friday to discuss what can be done to ensure low heating oil stocks don't hit consumers too hard this winter.
"What is spooking some people is this meeting on Friday," said Gerry Samuels, an analyst at U.S. Arb Oil.
Though the Energy Department has said it will not intervene in the market, there has been persistent speculation among traders that companies may volunteer action.
Exxon Corp is rumoured to have told clients that it will stop or at least curtail exports of distillates. The company declined to comment.
Dealers were divided on Thursday on whether oil markets had merely paused for breath before resuming their rise, or whether prices might be set for a heavier tumble.
Some saw signs of market fatigue after the bull run which carried crude up 40 percent in just four months.
"It's too high. I don't think the fundamentals can support prices at these levels," said a London-based trader.
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
Oct 17 Oct 16
(1515 GMT) (close)
Dated Brent $24.35 $24.54
IPE London Brent futures (Dec) $24.30 $23.94
NYMEX light crude futures (Nov) $25.43 $25.17
